Hooded Rosette Lichen

Physcia aipolia

Distinctive Trait

A pale gray rosette marked with black-rimmed apothecia — the signature “hooded” look that sets it apart from other Physcia species.

Hooded Rosette — Close View
Black-rimmed fruiting bodies stand out sharply against the pale gray thallus.
The apothecia appear as pale disks bordered by a distinct dark margin — the most reliable field mark of Physcia aipolia.
Size: 2376x3558

Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF 100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 800 • Aperture f/11 • Shutter 1/80 s

Description

Physcia aipolia, commonly known as Hooded Rosette Lichen, is a foliose lichen with a pale gray to bluish-gray thallus.
The surface often shows fine dark spotting, and the lobes have narrow dark edges that enhance its patterned look.

Its most defining trait is its apothecia: pale gray centers surrounded by striking black rims.
When colonies are abundant — as on old deciduous bark — they create a stippled constellation of rosettes.

It often grows alongside:

  • Candelaria concolor (Candleflame Lichen)
  • Flavoparmelia caperata (Common Greenshield)
  • Physcia millegrana (Powdery Shield)

Its presence is a good indicator of moderate air quality and stable bark chemistry.

Companion Community
A lichen mosaic featuring Hooded Rosette among Greenshield, Powdery Shield, and Candleflame.
This mixed community highlights the varied microhabitats on a single trunk.
Size: 6720x4480

Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF 100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 400 • Aperture f/8 • Shutter 1/200 s

Habitat

  • Bark of hardwoods
  • Well-lit exposures
  • Moderately clean air
  • Common in northern North America

Color & Structure

  • Pale gray to dark gray rosettes
  • Dark-margined lobes
  • Pale apothecia with black rims
  • Powdery or spotted upper surface

Size

  • 1–3 cm rosettes
  • Apothecia 0.5–1.5 mm wide

Images

Starburst Physcia with Candleflame Accents
Fine gray rosettes ringed with dark apothecia, contrasted by warm yellow flare-ups above.
A broad colony of Physcia aipolia spreads across the bark, its crisp lobes and circular, ink-rimmed apothecia forming a dense rosette pattern. Scattered patches of Candelaria concolor punctuate the scene with bright yellow, highlighting the varied communities that share the same tree surface.

Rosette Pattern
Interlocking rosettes with sharply defined apothecia.
A typical bark community arrangement.
Size: 4170x2780
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF 100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 800 • Aperture f/9 • Shutter 1/125 s

Apothecia Detail
Shows the characteristic black-rimmed fruiting bodies.
This is the key field mark separating aipolia from related species.
Size: 4170x2780
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF 100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 800 • Aperture f/10 • Shutter 1/100 s


Candleflame and Starburst Physcia
Golden crusts and pale rosettes sharing the same bark.
The vivid yellow of Candelaria concolor spreads in irregular patches while the white-gray rosettes of Physcia aipolia rise beside it, their ringed apothecia forming tiny starburst discs.
